awd_titl_txt: Pre-service Educators Reimagining Core Experiences in Physics Teaching
awd_abstract_narration:
The need to prepare a skilled and motivated STEM workforce who can meet the demands of a dynamic and complex global economy is a widely recognized national challenge.  This project, a cross-institutional collaboration among North Carolina State University, the University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill, and Davidson College, capitalizes on advances in technology to respond to that challenge.  It aims to provide empirical evidence on the enhancement of foundational physics concepts of pre-service elementary school teacher candidates, key players in the development of the STEM professional workforce, using haptically-enabled science simulations (HESSs).  Haptics is an umbrella term for the sense of touch (in this case virtual touch).  The HESSs are virtual representations of real-world systems, displayed visually, and augmented with haptic force-feedback.  Users can physically interact with multiple (often invisible) components of the modeled system (in this case) forces.  The project team's underlying premise is that if soon-to-be teachers (re)learn core physics concepts more deeply, they will be empowered to provide richer learning opportunities for their students.  This project will provide pre-service elementary school teachers access to ideas (in physics) and tools (technological and pedagogical) with the potential to influence how they approach the teaching of basic physics concepts in the elementary grades, as their students are just entering the STEM pipeline. 

This project targets two intertwined focal areas of the EHR Core Research (ECR) program: STEM workforce development and STEM learning and learning environments.  Building upon prior work involving HESSs, this project will work with undergraduate pre-service elementary school teachers to examine implications for the use of HESSs during their preparation. The project team will investigate pre-service elementary school teachers' understandings of forces as interactions (a foundational concept in physics) and the influence of haptic force-feedback technology.  The project adopts an embodied cognition perspective in the design, building, and testing of its intervention.  It uses a mixed-methods approach to examine the interfaces between teaching and learning and the mediation of STEM learning through fundamental use-inspired research.  The design, develop, and testing research cycle will include focus groups, usability testing, and small-scale pilot testing.  The pilot testing will use a pretest-posttest control group design with random assignment into two groups, haptic vs. non-haptic simulations.  This research has the potential to provide foundational knowledge for a new model of teaching about core physics concepts in the form of HESSs.  Project goals are to (1) add foundational human-computer interaction knowledge to guide the design, development, and testing of HESSs, (2) isolate and document the haptic influences on the development of teachers' specialized content knowledge of forces as interactions, and (3) study the pedagogical impact of the HESSs on pre-service elementary school teachers.  In addition to the benefits to the pre-service elementary teachers who participate, this project will train graduate research assistants and involve undergraduate students in cutting-edge STEM research, which also has the potential to contribute to STEM workforce development.  Project findings will be used to develop a set of design guidelines for the haptic-augmentation of science simulations that can be used by other researchers.  Moreover, cross-institutional and cross-disciplinary partnerships, such as this project, may enhance the infrastructure for STEM education and research.  This project is funded by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program, which supports fundamental research in STEM education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We often ask young learners to reason about things they can't see or experience directly in real-world scenarios. Imagine being able to interact with and "feel" the invisible aspects of science like the upthrust of a buoyant force on a jellyfish or the lift, thrust and drag acting on an airplane. Although still on the fringe of classroom learning technologies, haptics (simulated touch) has the potential to radically transform the way in which learners interact with science concepts. Haptics may help fill gaps in an individual's chain of reasoning about abstract ideas by providing simulated "concrete" experiences with invisible forces.

Teachers bring valuable experience and resources to their teaching of basic physics, but often tend to be less confident in their ability to teach it compared to the life sciences. In our project we aimed to combat "reasoning thin" elementary science curricula by using haptic force-feedback technology that may be able to tap into preservice teachers' intuitive physics ideas and help them construct consistent models. This process would in turn improve their teaching of basic physics with their students, laying the groundwork for future STEM learning. 

We have created and tested three (3) new Haptically-Enhanced Science Simulations (HESSs) addressingthe science concepts of (1) buoyancy, (2) forces and motion, and (3) the forces involved in flight. HESSs are virtual representations of real-world systems modeled computationally and augmented with haptic force-feedback that enables users to physically interact with multiple (often invisible) components of the modeled system (in this case forces in action). 

In our work we used an iterative design, develop, and testing research cycle that included: focus groups, pilot testing and user studies. We also developed and used a suite of assessment tools that adopted an embodied cognition perspective to tap into the bodily-based knowledge of physics that we all have. These included screen capture software, gesture analysis, rule and analogy creation, and two-tiered assessment tasks that required students to draw or interpret drawings and explain their reasoning. We have found that our Haptically-Enhanced Science Simulations (HESSs) can help learners move beyond "knowledge in pieces" that focuses on only one factor, to more relational and mechanistic explanations that integrate multiple factors into a more coherent whole. We saw this with sinking and floating concepts, as well as force and motion principles.

We also learned that levels of prior knowledge do indeed influence the ways in which users interact with our simulations. For example, when testing our Buoyancy HESS we saw that participants with high prior knowledge significantly improved performance when given both visual cues and haptic feedback in combination. However, participants with lower prior knowledge significantly improved when given haptic feedback alone whereas the combination of haptics with visual cues was not beneficial. We also came to realize that the users' "task awareness" (whether they understand the purpose and requirements of a given assessment task) really matters as researchers interpret participants' responses.  

Additionally, we were able to shed light on how to best represent force arrows in free-body diagrams, a fundamental tool used to support understanding of basic forces in action and ease the transition between scenario-based models and mathematical problem solving. We performed two user studies employing (1) static diagrams and (2) interactive simulations to explore if arrow placement impacted interpretation of force diagrams and comprehension of learning objectives, such as predicted motion. Results from both studies support the use of force arrows that appear to be pushing into the center of mass, or the edge of an object, as opposed to the traditional method of stemming from the center of mass. We suggest that a "push" arrow may be a more intuitive design that has the potential to facilitate novices' reasoning about foundational ideas involved with force and motion. This finding has implications for the creation of educational materials for the teaching of "forces in action".  

From a technological standpoint, the project resulted in a freely available and stable architecture for the integration of a haptic force-feedback device with a widely used game engine. This will enable others to create their own haptically-enabled scenarios. In terms of dissemination, our work has led to three (3) peer-reviewed publications and eleven (11) peer-reviewed presentations. It has involved two (2) graduate and eleven (11) different undergraduate students across two different institutions, exposing them to innovative educational research. The project has added foundational human-computer interaction (HCI) knowledge to guide the design, development, and testing of haptically-enabled science simulation (HESS) learning environments.
